Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Kinematic and Mechanical Alignment in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Sample size was calculated to detect a 5-point OKS difference with 80% power.

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if undergoing primary TKA, and the study was conducted at a single institution.

Intervention.evidence: In the KA group, patient-specific cutting blocks were created using preoperative MRI data, while the MA group used computer navigation for neutral alignment.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated whether kinematic alignment (KA) offers superior patient-reported outcomes compared to mechanical alignment (MA) in total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Oxford Knee Score (OKS), assessed preoperatively and at 6 weeks, 6 months, 1 year, and 2 years postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Ninety-nine primary TKAs in 95 patients were randomised to KA (n = 49) or MA (n = 50) groups.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 2 years, no significant difference was observed in OKS change scores between KA and MA groups (mean difference 1.0, 95% CI, âˆ’1.4 to 3.4, p = 0.4).

Harms.evidence: Complication rates were similar between groups, with no significant differences in adverse events.
